channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: First Lady Condemns Abduction of Nigerian Schoolgirls
item.description: Michelle Obama said that she and President Obama had been personally touched by the abduction of Nigerian schoolgirls by terrorists, calling it an “unconscionable” act.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: Michelle Obama spoke about Mother’s Day in the weekly radio address that is normally delivered by her husband.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The ‘Coming Home’ of Zhang Yimou and Gong Li
item.description: In “Coming Home,” Zhang Yimou examines China’s troubled political past and suggests how to deal with it today. With his legendary muse, Gong Li, playing the central character, the film represents a return to form for the director.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: South African Army Called In to Crack Down on Post-Election Unrest
item.description: The police arrested 59 people in the township of Alexandra, where protesters had burned tires and barricaded roads after the A.N.C’s election victory.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Residents walked in a barricaded street in the township of Alexandra, where the police used rubber bullets and stun grenades to disperse protesters.

item.title: China Says Goodbye in the Key of G: Kenny G
item.description: For years, Kenny G’s saxophone instrumental “Going Home” has been piped into shopping malls, schools, train stations and gyms in China as a signal to the public that it is time, indeed, to go.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: “Going Home,” by the saxophonist Kenny G, has become a staple of Chinese society.

item.title: Merkel and Hollande Send Russia a Warning
item.description: In a joint statement, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President François Hollande of France warned Russia that it would face tough sanctions if it did not help defuse the crisis in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, left, and President François Hollande of France, center, in Stralsund, Germany.

item.title: 2 Yemenis Shot by Americans Are Linked to Qaeda Cell
item.description: New details emerged about a shooting last month in which the Obama administration said two Americans from the U.S. Embassy killed armed Yemenis who were trying to kidnap them.
item.dc:creator: By SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The United States Embassy in Sana, Yemen's capital. The State Department said on Friday that two embassy officers shot and killed two assailants.

item.title: Amid Much Uncertainty, Separatists Prepare for Voting in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The referendums are likely to entrench pro-Russian militant groups, while putting the government in Kiev in the awkward position of contesting an election.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: In Indian Candidate, Hindu Right Sees a Reawakening
item.description: Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, an ideological group whose fortunes have ebbed and flowed with the influence of the Hindu right in New Delhi, has thrown its weight behind Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Narendra Modi, leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party and the front-runner for prime minister, flashed supporters the victory sign in Varanasi on Thursday.

item.title: Disease of Pakistan’s Poor Now Worries the Affluent
item.description: A World Health Organization recommendation that travelers not leave Pakistan without a polio vaccination certificate has sowed confusion.
item.dc:creator: By SABA IMTIAZ and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: A worker administering polio vaccine drops to a child at Jinnah International Airport in Karachi.

item.title: Stowaways Are Stranded in Mexico by Train Ban
item.description: Facing a lawsuit over violence on board its trains heading to the United States border, a railroad is no longer turning a blind eye to migrant stowaways.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: Women and children, among a group of 700 migrants from Central America, are transported in a police vehicle in Mexico.

item.title: Russia Ratchets Up Ukraine’s Gas Bills in Shift to an Economic Battlefield
item.description: Executives at the Russian gas giant Gazprom now say Ukraine owes them more than $22 billion, adding economic pressure to the military presence along Ukraine’s eastern border.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Joseph Sywenkyj for The New York Times
item.media:description: A metering station in Chaslovtsy, where gas pumped to the European Union via Ukraine is checked for volume and quality.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: More Chopsticks, Please
item.description: Traveling from Kiev to Hanoi within a matter of days was extremely revealing.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

item.title: Castrillo Matajudíos Journal: A Hard Sell to Tame a Name in Spain
item.description: The mayor of Castrillo Matajudíos, which translates roughly as Little Hill Fort of Jew Killers, is having a tough time persuading the village’s 56 registered inhabitants to support a new name.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Markel Redondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The 56 residents of Castrillo Matajudíos, about 160 miles from Madrid, are skeptical of a proposal to change the village’s name. Theories about its origin abound.

item.title: Brunei Ownership Casts a Shadow on a Beverly Hills Hotel
item.description: Since word spread of the turn in Brunei toward a harsh form of Islamic law by Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah, whose Brunei Investment Agency owns the Beverly Hills Hotel, Hollywood has turned its back on the hotel.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY
item.media:description: Workers at the Polo Lounge at the Beverly Hills Hotel, the target of a boycott over its ownership.

item.title: In Yemen, a Counterterrorism Challenge
item.description: The revelation that American agents killed two armed Yemenis complicates the Obama administration’s efforts to bolster President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, who has cooperated with drone strikes.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: A Simple Theory, and a Proposal, on H.I.V. in Africa
item.description: A team of Norwegian infectious disease specialists believes that African women are more vulnerable to H.I.V. because of a chronic, undiagnosed parasitic disease.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: The disease thought to contribute to the AIDS rate in African women is caused by worms picked up in infested river water.

item.title: From Crimea, Putin Trumpets Mother Russia
item.description: The Russian president traveled to Sevastopol, where he used the anniversary of victory over the Nazis to assert that Moscow had the right to annex the peninsula.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia attended a parade on Friday in Crimea, a territory which came under his control in March.

item.title: Philippines Jails Chinese Sailors in Fish Dispute
item.description: The dispute over the fishermen was one of two involving China over the last week, having been overshadowed by a clash between Chinese and Vietnamese ships.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Artist Detained Before Tiananmen Anniversary
item.description: Chinese public security agents have detained Chen Guang, 43, a former soldier turned artist whose experiences during those tumultuous days have become a haunting inspiration for his work.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Chen Guang, in 2009, in front of paintings based on his experiences during the suppression of the Tiananmen Square protests.

item.title: India Ink: A Second Conversation With: Times Now Editor Arnab Goswami
item.description: India Ink follows up with the television journalist, known for his aggressive interviews, after his one-on-one with Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA

item.title: Dalai Lama Urges Outside Inquiry Into Spate of Self-Immolations Among Tibetans
item.description: On a visit to Norway, where he was officially snubbed by officials eager to placate China, the spiritual leader also softened his stance against the suicidal form of protest.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL
item.media:description: The Dalai Lama greeting children from a Buddhist school during his visit to the Nobel Peace Center in Oslo on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Officers Kill Armed Civilians in Yemen Capital
item.description: A United States Special Operations commando and a C.I.A. officer killed two armed Yemeni civilians who tried to kidnap them in the capital two weeks ago, American officials said on Friday.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Yemenis gathered at the scene of a bomb blast that targeted a troop carrier near two Western embassies in Sana, the capital, on Friday. The barber-shop shooting happened two weeks ago.

item.title: In High Seas, China Moves Unilaterally
item.description: At least twice in recent years, Beijing has sought to explore the South China Sea but backed down after protests by Vietnam. That good will evaporated this week.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: In Ukrainian City Under Blockade, Citizens Go to Ground, and Below
item.description: Like many in the previously quiet industrial city of Slovyansk, Tatyana Vsevolodovna does not share the political passions of the men who stand at barricades with anti-tank rockets and guns.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neighbors of Tatyana Vsevolodovna (not pictured) talked in her basement, which is stocked with provisions bought in preparation for the outbreak of war.

item.title: Ukrainian Forces Attack Militant-Held Police Station
item.description: At least seven people were killed and 40 were injured as the government battled pro-Russian fighters in the city of Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Firefighters extinguished a blaze on Friday in Mariupol after fighting.
